video.title: Can you code on a phone? Android Mobile Programing Tutorial
video.description:
Learn tips and tricks for writing code on a mobile device.

✏️ Precious Oladele developed this course. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCLcHGKxbEO1XGVETXqzYXLA

📱 Get the official freeCodeCamp Android app: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=org.freecodecamp

🔗 Article about building a web app on a mobile phone: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/how-to-code-on-your-phone-python-pydroid-android-app-tutorial/

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Raymond Odero
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 aldo ferretti
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Xavery B.
topLevelComment.text: yes it is possible, even lowlevel languages like C. Today's android devies have a functionality to hook up to a TV or some monitor, if you wish. Second step is to get some OTG keyboard and mouse, or via bluetooth, to have phone connected to the power charger (which is most likely, what someone would do in such power draining situation). From this moment, you got almost normal PC. It isn't only impossible, but as comfortable, as on PC.

topLevelComment.author: djl
topLevelComment.text: Sailfish OS is another option. I sometimes play around with Python code on my Sailfish OS powered Sony Xperia. Your pretty much get a full-fledged Linux terminal to do what you want with Sailfish OS. In the past I had installed the ARM version of the JVM and used to play around with languages like Javascript (Rhino & Nashorn), Jython, Groovy and of course Java. Now days its just Python and some shell scripts :)

topLevelComment.author: Re Cecure
topLevelComment.text:
Reminds me of 12yo me coding on my nokia N70 Java + Symbian s60 v2. I used to have xplore file manager by lonely cat games. Bat scripts, c# .net framework code. Dedication was real. I used to write code by reading saved pages on opera mini and run them on my dad's PC.

I still code on my phone (Android) now. I now use Acode and nvim (termux). But most of it happens on my 8yo laptop now. :)

topLevelComment.text: But can you run the code directly on the machine? I'd like to see if I can train deep learning model on an M1 iPad.

replies.author: Vulnerable Growth
replies.text: @Samartha J yes, but they have the same hardware. It should be a matter of being able to put the data on the GPU whether it’s an iPad or Macbook. The issue is that there is no IDE and backend to run code on an iPad even if the hardware is there.

replies.author: Samartha J
replies.text: @Vulnerable Growth he is talking about m1 ipad not macbook

replies.author: Message grayhat_hacks on Instagram for help
Vulnerable Growth
replies.text: @Michael Mantion I work in AI. Models can be trained on the M1 macbooks very fast so it shouldn’t take that long and electricity is really not that big of an issue (overblown virtue signalling). Anyway, unless you are training transformer models from scratch, it’s not an issue. Fine-tuning a model should not take more than a few hours if you can access the M1 GPU.

replies.author: Michael Mantion
replies.text: You can, but more complex algos might take years and waste a lot of electricity.

topLevelComment.author: Mr76Pontiac
topLevelComment.text: As much as I can appreciate that there are the tools and utilities and methods to do this, I'd personally never do any kind of development work on a mobile device.  I absolutely hate the keyboard interface of any mobile device.  Having to switch "keyboards" to get to the special characters, a small screen, lack of screen real estate... It'd drive me nuts in the first 30 seconds.  I hate even doing text messaging on a phone.

replies.author: Message grayhat_hacks on Instagram for help
Phani Gautam
replies.text: @Mr76Pontiac ya, i get where you are coming from, while my family is not rich, I have access to a good laptop and internet connectioncand I take it for granted how much I can learn with ease. i am never gonna complain about lack of resources, so I don't understand what people had to go through.

replies.author: Mr76Pontiac
replies.text:
​@Phani Gautam I'm just speaking from my own experience of what I had in the 80s vs what I have now, and having the understanding of what my phone is used for vs what a web site is used for.  Back in the day, I was limited to a single 40x23 CHARACTER screen, and having that machine run at 1mhz (Not Ghz).  I had only books and magazines my dad purchased.  I had only whatever was provided at the local library, which was NOT MUCH AT ALL.  Believe me, I know what the limitations are, both then and now.  Those with the drive to learn will figure out how to learn.  I'm not arguing your point, not for a second, as I absolutely agree with it.

But, even on that Commodore 64, I had a proper keyboard that took EXACTLY zero screen real-estate.  I had easy access to type things such as quotes, symbols, numbers, changing the case of the characters...  I suppose if one were to get a Bluetooth or USB keyboard/mouse with appropriate adapters, it'd make life SO much easier, and I could maybe deal with that for 30 minutes or such.  But JUST a phone?  JUST a tablet?  No way, not for me.
